sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Female hirsutism, Facial: apply 13.9% cream as a thin layer to affected areas of the face twice daily, application should be at least 8 hours apart and cream should remain on skin for at least 4 hours
  • Trypanosomiasis: 100 mg/kg IV over at least 45 min every 6 h for 14 days

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• safety and efficacy has not been established in pediatric patients
  • Female hirsutism, Facial: (12 y and older) apply 13.9% cream as a thin layer to affected areas of the face twice daily, application should be at least 8 hours apart and cream should remain on skin for at least 4 hours

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono: renal impairment: slower excretion of eflornithine occurs with renal impairment; dosing should be adjusted based on CrCl, however, specific dosing recommendations are not available

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono: pre-existing bone marrow suppression or hematologic abnormalities

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• Eflornithine: WHO: WHO documentation states insufficient data.
  • Eflornithine: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
Dermatologic:Acne, With topical cream, Stinging of skin, Topical cream
Serious
  • Hematologic:Myelosuppression, IV dose form (14-55%), Thrombocytopenia, IV dose form (14-48%)
  • Neurologic:Seizure, IV dose form (8%)
  • Otic:Ototoxicity, IV dose form

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Eflornithine hydrochloride is thought to irreversibly inhibits skin ornithine decarboxylase (ODC). This activity suppresses cell division and synthesis, which affect hair growth.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Topical
  • apply thin layer to affected areas of face and adjacent involved areas under chin; rub in thoroughly; apply at least 5 minutes after hair removal
  • do not wash treated area for at least 4 h
  • may apply cosmetics or sunscreens after cream has dried

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• The cream may cause acne or stinging.
  • Advise patient it may be several weeks before improvement is seen. However, drug should not be used longer than 6 mo if it does not appear to be working.
  • Inform patient that the effects of this drug are not permanent. Once discontinued, hair growth will likely return.
  • Patient should apply drug at least 5 min after hair removal and should not wash treated area for at least 4 h after administration.
  • Patient may apply cosmetics or sunscreens after the cream has dried.
  • If a dose has been missed, apply as soon as possible and then wait at least 8 h until the next application.
